Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Developmental breakdown and abnormal growth in hybrid dwarf hamsters
Award.AbstractNarration:
A major goal in biology is to understand the origin of biological diversity. The source and persistence of new species is closely linked to the formation of barriers to successful reproduction between species. One common barrier that arises in mammals is abnormal development of hybrid placentas resulting in unusually large or small hybrid offspring. This recurrent pattern indicates that the genes and molecular pathways that control development may often be disrupted in mammalian hybrids. We will use several experiments with hybrid dwarf hamsters to bridge significant gaps in our understanding of the genetic causes of extreme embryonic and placental overgrowth. First, high-throughput DNA sequencing experiments of large- and normal-sized placenta will be used to identify areas of the genome that cause overgrowth. Second, genomic experiments will be used to determine if the disruption of gene regulation in the placenta causes hybrid overgrowth. Together, these experiments will use a powerful laboratory model to begin to uncover the genetic causes of abnormal mammalian growth during the early stages of development.

This work will use cutting-edge methods to address fundamental questions on the nature of species formation and divergence in mammals. This research will also advance the study of developmental diseases by providing insights into the genetic causes of abnormal growth in developing placentas and embryos. Furthermore, the proposed activities will provide training and support for a graduate student and facilitate the mentoring of undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal in biology is to understand the origin of biological diversity. The source and persistence of new species is closely linked to the formation of barriers to successful reproduction between species. One common barrier that arises in mammals is abnormal development and growth of hybrid offspring. This abnormal growth is most apparent in placentas and results in unusually large or small hybrid offspring. Abnormal development is found in the hybrids of many mammals, for instance two examples are mules (horse x donkey) and ligers (lion x tiger), both of which are much larger than the parent species. This recurrent pattern indicates that the genes that control embryonic development may often be disrupted in the placentas of mammalian hybrids. Our goal for this research was to use several experiments with hybrid dwarf hamsters to uncover the genetic and epigenetic causes of extreme embryonic and placental overgrowth.

            Using next-generation DNA sequencing approaches, we found that differences between the X chromosomes of the two parent species are the primary cause of extreme placental overgrowth.  We also found that the epigenetic regulation of the X chromosome is not disrupted in hybrids, implying that sequence differences in the genes on the X chromosome is likely important. Finally, we found that the epigenetic regulation of many autosomal genes (genes not on the X or Y chromosomes) is disrupted, and that these genes are likely to be specifically involved in embryonic growth.

            These results directly inform our understanding of the roles that gene regulation and sex chromosomes play in the origin of new species. This research also has direct applications to a number of human diseases including many types of cancers, Prader-Willi syndrome and Angleman syndrome, all of which are caused by disruptions in the same genes and developmental growth pathways that we identified in hamsters.
